oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Tennessee & Western North Carolina showing mineral deposits in vicinity of Knoxville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Maps; Mineral deposits; Railroads; Rivers; Streams; Boundaries; Geology; Cities & towns
Agriculture; Maps; Geology; Minerals; Railroads
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The map is a reproduction from unknown origin. It indicates railroads completed, in construction, and proposed; topographical features; cities and towns; rivers, creeks and streams; the border states of Kentucky, Virginia, Georgia, and North Carolina; and copper and iron ore deposits.The border lines and ore deposits are hand marked in color ink. It is noted that “the iron deposits South of Knoxville at Chilhowee Mountain, Tellico River and Starr’s Mountain are not Dyestone but Limonite.” Scale (1:633,600)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Charles Waring & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map demonstrates the rich mineral resources available for potential manufacturers in Tennessee during the nineteenth century. At the time, northern investors were purchasing huge acreages in mineral rich areas of Appalachia. Tennessee was an early leader in iron ore production. However, by the beginning of the twentieth century, the focus shifted to coal mining.
